habitat_description:
Larus glaucescens nests on gravel beaches (Hoffman et al., 1978; Good, 2002; Henson et al., 2004), sand beaches (Hoffman et al., 1978; Zenier et al., 1990), grassy balds and grass/shrub headlands (Hoffman et al., 1978; Good, 2002; Hayward and Verbeek, 2008; see also: Stout, 1975; Phillips et al., 2005; RBCM, 2010), rock outcrops and cliffs (Zenier et al., 1990; Hayward and Verbeek, 2008; RBCM, 2010), rooftops, pilings, piers, and bridges (Phillips et al., 2005; Heyward and Verbeek, 2008; RBCM, 2010), even within developed urban cores (Hooper, 1988; Vermeer et al., 1988). In Victoria, BC, The maximum distance of a nest site from saltwater was roughly 500 m (Hooper, 1988).

The species forages on open water (Zenier et al., 1990; Binford and Johnson, 1995; Phillips et al., 2005), both mud and rock intertidal areas (Hayward and Verbeek, 2008), beaches (Zenier et al., 1990), and landfills (Zenier et al., 1990; Binford and Johnson, 1995; Heyward and Verbeek, 2008).

L. glaucescens tends to avoid habitats with trees or thick shrub (Heyward and Verbeek, 2008).

Generally associated with maritime environments, the glaucous-winged gull has also been documented in freshwater and hundreds of kilometers up the Columbia River (Wahl, 1972; Rogers, 1981; Conover and Thompson, 1984; Weber and Fitzner, 1986). In these interior environments, the gull can be found up to 1200 m in elevation (RBCM, 2010). The species has also been documented hundreds of miles from shore (Zenier et al., 1990; RBCM, 2010).
